editionStmt.edition: This early release includes some 500 EEBO-TCP transcriptions of Early Modern plays that have undergone several routines to create an interoperable and algorithmically amenable corpus of Early Modern Drama. Many incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words have been corrected, including obvious printers' errors, but the text has not been proofread word by word. Each word in the text has been identified as a distinct token with its own xml:id and assigned to a lemma, a part of speech, and a standard spelling. Speech prefixes were mapped to unique speaker ID's as "who" attributes of sp elements. elements

respStmt.resp: Incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words were reviewed and in many cases fixed by
respStmt.name: Madeline Burg

respStmt.resp: Tokenization and linguistic annotation using MorphAdorner and NUPOS 2.0 were provided by
respStmt.name: Philip R. Burns

respStmt.resp: With the help of Thomas L. Berger's Index of Characters in Early Modern English Drama Printed Plays, 1500-1660 speech prefixes were mapped to unique "who" attributes of sp elements by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: A provisional, rudimentry, and algorithmically produced castlist was added as a new div in the back listing each role with their number of speeches sorted from high to low by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: Project co-ordination and review of textual changes and linguistic annotation by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

div.p: London: printed by T. s. for Thomas archer, and are to be sold at his shop in popes-head-palace, near the Royal-exchange. 1613.

div.stage: The countess of Swevia discovered sitting at a table covered with black, on which stands two black tapers lighted, she in mourning.
Enter Roberto count of cypress, Gvido count of Arsena, and signior Mizaldus.

sp.speaker: Mizaldus.
sp.l: What should we do in this countesses dark hole?
She's sullenly retired, as the turtle:
sp.p: Every day has been a black day with her since her husband died, and what should we unruly members make here?

sp.speaker: Guid.
sp.l: As melancholy night masques up heaven's face,
So doth the evening-star present herself
Unto the careful shepherd's gladsome eyes,
By which unto the fold he leads his flock.

sp.speaker: Mizald.
sp.p: Zounds what a sheepish beginning is here? 'tis said true, love is simple; and it may well hold, and thou art a simple lover.

sp.speaker: Rober.
sp.l: See how yond star like beauty in a cloud,
Illumines darkness, and beguiles the moon
Of all her glory in the firmament.

sp.speaker: Mizal.
sp.p: Well said man i'the moon. Was ever such astronomers? Marry I fear none of these will fall into the right ditch.

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: Madam.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Ha Anna, what are my doors unbarred?

sp.speaker: Miz.
sp.p: I'll assure you the way into your ladyship is open.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: And God defend that any profane hand
Should offer sacrilege to such a saint.
Lovely Isabella, by this duteous kiss,
That draws part of my soul along with it,
Had I but thought my rude intrusion
Had waked the dovelike spleen harboured within you,
Life and my first born should not satisfy
Such a transgression, worthy of a check,
But that immortals wink at my offence,
Makes me presume more boldly: I am come
To raise you from this so infernal sadness.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: My lord of cypress, do not mock my grief:
Tears are as due a tribute to the dead,
As fear to God, and duty unto Kings.
Love to the just, or hate unto the wicked.

sp.speaker: Rober.
sp.l: Surcease.
Believe it is a wrong unto the gods:
They sail against the wind that wail the dead.
And since his heart hath wrestled with death's pangs,
From whose stern cave none tracts a backward path.
Leave to lament this necessary change,
And thank the gods, for they can give as good.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: I wail his loss! Sink him ten cubits deeper,
I may not fear his resurrection:
I will be sworn upon the holy writ
I morn thus fervent cause, he died no sooner:
He buried me alive,
And mued me up like Cretan Dedalus,
And with wall-eyed jealousy kept me from hope
Of any waxen wings to fly to pleasure.
But now his soul her Argos eyes hath closed,
and I am free as air. You of my sex,
In the first flow of youth use you the sweets
Due to your proper beauties, ere the ebb
And long wane of unwelcome change shall come.
Fair women play: she's chaste whom none will have.
Here is a man of a most mild aspect,
Temperate, effeminate, and worthy love,
One that with burning ardour hath pursued me:
A donative he hath of every God;
Apollo gave him locks, Jove his high front,
The god of eloquence his flowing speech,
The feminine deities strowed all their bounties
And beauty on his face: that eye was Juno's,
Those lips were his that won the golden ball,
That virgin-blush Diana's: here they meet,
As in a sacred synod. My lords, I must entreat
A while your wished forbearance.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: We obey you lady. Exit Guido and Mizald. Ma. Rob.

sp.speaker: Is.
sp.l: My lord, with you I have some conference.
I pray my lord, do you woo every lady
In this phrase you do me?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Fairest, till now,
Love was an infant in my oratory.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: And kiss thus too?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: I ne'er was so kissed, leave thus to please,
Flames into flames, seas thou pourest into seas.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: Pray frown my lord, let me see how many wives
You'll have. Heigh-ho, you'll bury me I see.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: In the swans down, and tomb thee in mine arms.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: Then folks shall pray in vain to send me rest.
Away, you're such another meddling lord.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: By heaven my love's as chaste as thou art fair,
And both exceed comparison: by this kiss,
That crowns me monarch of another world
Superior to the first, fair, thou shalt see
As unto heaven, my love so unto thee.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: Alas poor creatures, when we are once o'the falling hand,
a man may easily come over us.
It is as hard for us to hide our love,
As to shut sin from the creator's eyes.
I'faith my lord, I had a month's mind unto you,
As tedious as a full riped maidenhead.
And count of cypress, think my love as pure,
As the first opening of the blooms in may;
Your virtue's man; nay, let me not blush to say so:
And see for your sake thus I leave to sorrow.
Begin this subtle conjuration with me,
And as this taper, due unto the dead,
I here extinguish, so my late dead lord
I put out ever from my memory,
That his remembrance may not wrong our love. Puts out the taper.
As boldfaced women when they wed another,
Banquet their husbands with their dead love's heads.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: And as I sacrifice this to his ghost,
With this expire all corrupt thoughts of youth,
That fame-insatiate devil jealousy,
And all the sparks that may bring unto flame,
Hate betwixt man and wife or breed defame.

div.stage: Enter Mizaldus and Mendosa.

sp.speaker: Guid.
sp.p: Marry amen, I say: madam, are you that were in for all day, now come to be in for all night? How now count Arsena?

sp.speaker: Miz.
sp.l: Faith signior not unlike the condemned malefactor,
That hears his judgement openly pronounced;
But I ascribe to fate, joy swell your love,
Cypress, and willow grace my drooping crest.

sp.speaker: Rober.
sp.l: We do intend our hymeneal rights
With the next rising sun. Count cypress,
Next to our bride, the welcom'st to our feast.

sp.speaker: Count. Ars.
sp.l: Saneta Maria, what thinkst thou of this change?
A player's passion I'll believe hereafter,
And in a tragic scene weep for old Priam,
When fell revenging Pyrrhus with supposed
And artificial wounds mangles his breast,
and think it a more worthy act to me,
Then trust a female mourning o'er her love:
Naught that is done of woman shall me please,
Nature's stepchildren rather her desire.

sp.speaker: Miz.
sp.l: Learn of a well composed epigram,
A woman's love, and thus 'twas sung unto us:
The tapers that stood on her husband's hearse,
Isabell' advances to a second bed:
Is it not wondrous strange for to rehearse
She should so soon forget her husband dead;
One hour? for if the husband's life once fade,
Both love and husband in one grave are laid.
But we forget ourselves, I am for the marriage
Of signior Claridiana, and the fine mrs. Abigall.

sp.speaker: Count. Ars.
sp.p: I for his arch-foes wedding signior Rogero, and the spruce mrs. Thais: but see, the solemn rites are ended, and from their several temples they are come.

sp.speaker: Mizal.
sp.p: A quarrel on my life.

div.stage: Enter at one door signior Claridiana, Abigal his wife, the lady Lentulus with rosemary as from church. At the other door signior Rogero and Thais his wife, Mendosa foscarii, nephew to the Duke, from the bridal, they see one another, and draw, count Arsena and others step between them.

sp.speaker: Clarid.
sp.p: Good my lord detain me not, I will tilt at him.

sp.speaker: Rogero.
sp.l: Remember, sir, this is your wedding day,
And that triumph belongs only to your wife.

sp.speaker: Rogero.
sp.p: If you be noble let me cut off his head.

sp.speaker: Clarid.
sp.p: Remember o'the other side, you have a maidenhead of your own to cut off.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: I'll make my marriage day like to the bloody bridal Alcides by the fiery Centaurs had.

sp.speaker: Thais.
sp.p: Husband, dear husband!

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: Away with these catterwallers.
Come on sir.

sp.speaker: Clarid.
sp.p: Thou son of a Jew.

sp.speaker: Guid.
sp.p: Alas poor wench, thy husband's circumcised.

sp.speaker: Clarid.
sp.l: Begotten when thy father's face was towards th'east,
To show that thou wouldst prove a caterpillar:
His Messias shall not save thee from me,
I'll send thee to him in collops.

sp.speaker: Arsen.
sp.p: O fry not in choler so sir.

sp.speaker: Roger.
sp.l: Mountebank with thy pedantical action,
Rimatrix, buglors, rhimocers.

sp.speaker: Mend.
sp.l: Gentlemen, I conjure you
By the virtues of men.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Shall any broken quacksalver's bastard oppose him to me in my nuptials? No, but I'll show him better mettle than ere the gallimaufry his father used. Thou scum of his melting pots, that wert christened in a crucible, with Mercury's water, to show thou wouldst prove a stinging Aspis; for all thou spit'st is aqua fortis, and thy breath is a compound of poison's stillatory: if I get within thee, hadst thou the scaly hide of a crocodile, as thou art partly of his nature, I would leave thee as bare as an anatomy at the second viewing.

sp.speaker: Clarid.
sp.p: Thou Jew, of the tribe of gad, that sure, there were none here but thou and I, wouldst teach me the art of breathing, thou wouldst run like a dromedary.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Thou that art the tall'st man of Christendom; when thou art alone, if thou dost maintain this to my face, I'll make thee skip like an ounce.

sp.speaker: Mend.
sp.p: Nay, good sir, be you still.

sp.speaker: Roger.
sp.l: Let the quacksalver's son be still:
His father was still, and still, and still again.

sp.speaker: Clarid.
sp.p: By the almighty I'll study negromancy but I'll be revenged.

sp.speaker: Arsen.
sp.l: Gentlemen, leave these dissensions,
Signior Rogero, you are a man of worth.

sp.speaker: Clarid.
sp.p: True, all the city points at him for a knave.

sp.speaker: Arsen.
sp.l: You are of like reputation signior Claridiana:
The hatred twixt your grandsire's first began,
Impute it to the folly of that age.
These your dissensions may erect a faction,
like to the Capulets and Montagues.

sp.speaker: Mend.
sp.l: Put it to equal arbitration, choose your friends,
The senators will think 'em happy in't.

sp.speaker: Miz.
sp.p: I'll ne'er embrace the smoke of a furnace, the quintessence of mineral or simples, or as I may say more learnedly, nor the spirit of quicksilver.

sp.speaker: Clarid.
sp.p: Nor I such a centaur, half a man, half an ass, and all a Jew.

sp.speaker: Arsen.
sp.p: Nay, than we will be constables, and force a quiet:Exeunt all the men. Manet Lent. Thais. Abig. and Mend.gentlemen, keep 'em asunder, and help to persuade 'em.

sp.speaker: Mend.
sp.p: Well ladies, your husbands behave 'em as lustily on their wedding days, as ere I heard any. Nay lady widow, you and I must have a falling: you're of signior Mizaldus' faction, and I am your vowed enemy, from the bodkin to the pincase. Hark in your ear.

sp.speaker: Abigall.
sp.p: Well Thais, oh you're a cunning carver: we two that any time these fourteen years have called sisters, brought and bred up together: that have told one another all our wanton dreams, talked all nightlong of young men, and spent many an idle hour, fasted upon the stones on s. Agnes night together, practised all the petulant amorousnesses that delights young maids, yet have you concealed not only the marriage, but the man: and well you might deceive me, for I'll be sworn you never dreamed of him, and it stands against all reason you should enjoy him you never dreamed of.

sp.speaker: Thais.
sp.p: Is not all this the same in you? Did you ever manifest your sweetheart's nose, that I might nose him by't? commended his calf, or his nether-lip? apparent signs that you were not in love or wisely covered it. Have you ever said, such a man goes upright, or has a better gate than any of the rest, as indeed, since he is proved a magnifico, I thought thou wouldst have put it into my hands whate'er 'thad been.

sp.speaker: Abig.
sp.p: Well wench, we have cross fates: our husbands such inveterate foes, and we such entire friends, but the best is we are neighbours, and our back arbours may afford visitation freely: prithee let us maintain our familiarity still whatsoever thy husband do unto thee, as I am afraid he will cross it i'the nick.

sp.speaker: Thais.
sp.p: Faith, you little one, if I please him in one thing, he shall please me in all, that's certain. Who shall I have to keep my counsel if I miss thee? who shall teach me to use the bridle, when the reins are in mine own hand? what to long for? when to take physic? where to be melancholy? why, we two are one another's grounds, without which would be no music.

sp.speaker: Abig.
sp.p: Well said wench, and the pricksong we use shall be our husbands.

sp.speaker: Thais.
sp.p: I will long for swines-flesh o'the first child.

sp.speaker: Abig.
sp.l: Wilt'ou little Jew? And I to kiss thy husband
Upon the least belly-ache. This will mad 'em.

sp.speaker: Thais.
sp.p: I kiss thee wench for that, and with it confirm our friendship.

sp.speaker: Mend.
sp.p: By these sweet lips widow.

sp.speaker: Lady Lent.
sp.l: Good my lord learn to swear by rote:
Your birth and fortune makes my brain suppose,
That like a man heated with wines and lust,
She that is next your object is your mate,
Till the foul water have quenched out the fire.
You the Duke's kinsman, tell me, I am young,
Fair, rich, and virtuous; I myself will flatter
Myself, till you are gone, that are more fair,
More rich, more virtuous, and more debonair:
All which are ladders to an higher reach:
Who drinks a puddle that may taste a spring?
Who kiss a subject that may hug a King?

sp.speaker: Mend.
sp.l: Yes, the camel always drinks in puddle water,
And as for huggings read antiquities.
Faith, madam, I'll board thee one of these days.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Ay, but ne'er bed me my lord: my vow is firm
Since God hath called me to this noble state,
Much to my grief, of virtuous widowhood,
No man shall ever come within my gates.

sp.speaker: Mend.
sp.l: Wilt thou ram up thy porch-hold? O widow, I perceive
You're ignorant of the lovers legerdemain .
There is a fellow that by magic will assist
To murder princes invisible, I can command his spirit.
Or what say you to a fine scaling ladder of ropes?
I can tell you, I am a mad wag-halter:
But by the virtue I see seated in you,
And by the worthy fame is blazoned of you,
By little Cupid, that is mighty named,
And can command my looser follies down,
I love, and must enjoy â–ª yet with such limits,
As one that knows enforced marriage
To be the fury's sister. Think of me.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Mend.
sp.p: How now lady, does the toy take you, as they say?

sp.speaker: Abig.
sp.p: No, my lord, nor do we take your toy, as they say. This is a child's birth, that must not be delivered before a man, though your lordship might be a midwife for your chin.

sp.speaker: Mend.
sp.p: Some bawdy riddle is't not? you long till't be night.

sp.speaker: Thais.
sp.p: No, my lord, women's longing comes after their marriage night. Sister, see you be constant now.

sp.speaker: Abig.
sp.p: Why, dost think I'll make my husband a cuckold? O here they come.

div.stage: Enter at several doors count Ars. with Claridiana: Gvido, with Rogero, at another door, Mendosa meets them.

sp.speaker: Mend.
sp.p: Signior Rogero, are you yet qualified?

sp.speaker: Rogero.
sp.p: Yes: does any man think I'll go like a sheep to the slaughter? Hands off my lord, your lordship may chance come under my hands: if you do, I shall show myself a citizen, and revenge basely.

sp.speaker: Clarid.
sp.l: I think if I were receiving the holy sacrament
His sight would make me gnash my teeth terribly:
But there's the beauty without parallel,To Abigall.
In whom the graces and the virtue's meet:
In her aspect mild honour sits and smiles:
And who looks there, were it the savage bear,
But would derive new nature from her eyes.
But to be reconciled simply for him,
Were mankind to be lost again, I'd let it,
And a new heap of stones should stock the world.
In heaven and earth this power beauty hath,
it inflames temperance, and temp'rates wrath:
Whate'er thou art, mine art thou wise or chaste:
I shall set hard upon thy marriage vow,
And write revenge high in thy husband's brow,
In a strange character. You may begin sir.

sp.speaker: Mend.
sp.l: Signior Claridiana, I hope signior Rogero
Thus employed me about a good office,
'Twere worthy Cicero's tongue, a famous oration now?
But friendship that is mutually embraced of the gods,
And is Jove's usher to each sacred synod,
Without the which he could not reign in heaven,
That overgoes my admiration shall not undergo my censure.
These hot flames of rage, that else will be
As fire midst your nuptial jollity,
Burning the edge off from the present joy,
And keep you wake to terror.

sp.speaker: Clarid.
sp.p: I have not yet swallowed the rhimatrix nor the onocentaur, the rhinoceros was monstrous.

sp.speaker: Arsen.
sp.p: Sir, be you of the more flexible nature, and confess an error.

sp.speaker: Clarid.
sp.l: I must, the gods of love command,
And that bright star, her eye, that guides my fate.
Signior Rogero, joy then signior Rogero.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Signior, sir, oh devil.

sp.speaker: Thais.
sp.l: Good husband show yourself a temperate man,
Your mother was a woman I dare swear;
No tiger got you, nor no bear was rival
In your conception: you seem like the issue
The painter's limb leaping from envy's mouth,
That devours all he meets.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: Had the last, or the least syllable
Of this more than immortal eloquence,
Commenced to me when rage had been so high
Within my blood, that it o'ertopped my soul,
Like to the lion when he hears the sound
Of Dian's bowstring in some shady wood,
I should have couched my lowly limb on earth,
and held my silence a proud sacrifice.

sp.speaker: Clarid.
sp.l: Slave, I will fight with thee at any odds,
Or name an instrument fit for destruction,
That ne'er was made to make away a man,
I'll meet thee on the ridges of the Alps,
Or some inhospitable wilderness,
Stark naked, at push-of-pike, or keen curtle-axe,
At Turkish sickle, Babylonian saw,
The ancient hooks of great Cadwalleder,
Or any other heathen invention.

sp.speaker: Thais.
sp.p: O God bless the man.

sp.speaker: Lent.
sp.p: Counsel him good my lord.

sp.speaker: Mend.
sp.l: Our tongues are weary, and he desperate,
He does refuse to hear: what shall we do?

sp.speaker: Clarid.
sp.l: I am not mad, I can hear, I can see, I can feel,
But a wise rage in man, wrongs passed compare,
Should be well nourished as his virtues are:
I'd have it known unto each valiant spirit.
He wrongs no man that to himself does right.
Catzo I ha'done, signior Rogero, I ha'done.

sp.speaker: Arsen.
sp.l: By heaven this voluntary reconciliation made
Freely, and of itself, argues unfeigned
And virtuous knot of love. So sirs embrace.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: Sir, by the conscience of a Catholic man,
And by our mother church that binds
And doth atone in amity with God,
The souls of men, that they with men be one,
I tread into the centre all the thoughts
Of ill in me, towards you, and memory
Of what from you might ought disparage me,
Wishing unfeignedly it may sink low,
And as untimely births want power to grow.

sp.speaker: Mend.
sp.p: Christianly said: signior what would you have more?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: And so I swear, you're honest onocentaur.

sp.speaker: Arsen.
sp.l: Nay see now, fie upon your turbulent spirit,
Did he do't in this form?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p:
If you think not this sufficient, you shall command
me to be reconciled in another form, as a rhimatrix or a rhinoceros.

sp.speaker: Mend.
sp.p: 'Sblood, what will you do?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Well, give me your hands first, I am friends with you i'faith: thereupon I embrace you, kiss your wife, and God give us joy. To Thais.

sp.speaker: Thais.
sp.p: You mean me and my husband.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: You take the meaning better than the speech, lady.

sp.speaker: Roger.
sp.l: The like wish I, but ne'er can be the like,
And therefore wish I thee.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: By this bright light that is derived from thee.

sp.speaker: Thais.
sp.p: So sir, you make me a very light creature.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: But that thou art a blessed angel, sent
Down from the gods t'atone mortal men,
I would have thought deeds beyond all men's thoughts,
And executed more upon his corpse:
O let him thank the beauty of this eye,
And not his resolute sword or destiny.

sp.speaker: Arsen.
sp.l: What sayest thou Mizaldus, come applaud this jubilee,
A day these hundred years before not truly known,
To these divided factions.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: No nor this day had it been falsely born,
But that I mean to sound it with his horn.

sp.speaker: Miz.
sp.p: I liked the former jar better: than they showed like men and soldiers; now like cowards and lechers.

sp.speaker: Arsen.
sp.p: Well said Mizaldus: thou art like the base viol in a consort, let the other instrument wish and delight in your highest sense, thou art still grumbling.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Nay, sweet receive it,Gives it Abigall.
And in it my heart:
And when thou readest a moving syllable
Think that my soul was secretary to't.
It is your love, and not the odious wish
Of my revenge, in styling him a cuckold,
Makes me presume thus far: then read it fair,
My passion's ample as your beauties are.

sp.speaker: Abig.
sp.p: Well sir, we will not stick with you.

sp.speaker: Arsena.
sp.l: And gentlemen, since it hath happed so fortunately,
I do entreat we may all meet tomorrow,
In some heroic masque, to grace the nuptials
Of the most noble countess of Swevia.

sp.speaker: Mend.
sp.p: Who does the young count marry?

sp.speaker: Arsen.
sp.l: O sir, who but the very heir of all her sex,
That bears the palm of beauty from 'em all:
Others compared to her, show like faint stars
To the full moon of wonder in her face:
The lady Isabella, the late widow
To the deceased and noble viscount Hermut.

sp.speaker: Mend.
sp.l: La you there, widow, there's one of the last edition,
Whose husband yet retains in his cold trunk
Some little airing of his noble guest,
Yet she a fresh bride as the month of May.

sp.speaker: Lent.
sp.l: Well my lord, I am none of these,
That have my second husband bespoke,
My door shall be a testimony of it.
And but these noble marriages incite me,
My much abstracted presence should have showed it.
If you come to me, hark in your ear my lord,
Look your ladder of ropes be strong,
For I shall tie you to your tackling.

sp.speaker: Arsen.
sp.p: Gentlemen, your answer to the masque.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Your honour leads, we'll follow.

sp.speaker: Rogero.
sp.p: Signior Claridiana.

sp.speaker: Clarid.
sp.p: I attend you sir. Exeunt omnes. Manet Clarid.

sp.speaker: Abigall.
sp.p: You'll be constant.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Above the adamant the goat's blood shall not break me,
Yet shallow fools, and plainer moral men,
That understand not what they undertake,
Fall in their own snares, or come short of vengeance,
No, let the sun view with an open face,
And afterwards shrink in his blushing cheeks,
Ashamed, and cursing of the fixed decree,
That makes his light bawd to the crimes of men,
When I have ended what I now devise.
Apollo's oracle shall swear me wise,
Strumpet his wife, branch my false-seeming friend,
And make him foster what my hate begotten,
A bastard, that when age and sickness seize him,
Shall be a corrosive to his griping heart:
I'll write to her, for what her modesty
Will not permit, nor my adulterate forcing,
That blushless herald shall not fear to tell:
Rogero shall know yet that his foe's a man,
And what is more, a true Italian. Exit.

div.head: Actus secundi
Scaena prima.
div.stage: Enter Roberto, lord Cardinal, Isabella, lady Lentulus, Abigal and Thais. Lights.

sp.speaker: Roberto.
sp.l: My grave lord Cardinal, we congratulate,
And zealously do entertain your love:
That from your high and divine contemplation,
You have vouchsafed to consummate a day
Due to our nuptials: oh, may this knot you knit,
This individual gordiant grasp of hands,
In sight of God so fairly intermixed,
Never be severed, as heaven smiles at it,
By all the darts shot by infernal Jove,
Angels of grace amen, amen, say to't.
Fair lady widow, and my worthy mistress,
Do you keep silence for a wager?

sp.speaker: Thais.
sp.l: Do you ask a woman that question my lord,
When she enforcedly pursues what she's forbidden?
I think if I had been tied to silence,
I should have been worthy the cucking-stool ere this time.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: You shall not be my orator (Lady) that pleads thus for yourself.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: My lord, the masquers are at hand.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Give them kind entertainment. Some worthy friends of mine, my lord, unknown to me, too lavish of their loves, bring their own welcome in a solemn masque.

sp.speaker: Abigall.
sp.l: I am glad there's noblemen i'the masque
With our husbands to overrule them,
They had shamed us all else.

sp.speaker: Thais.
sp.p: Why? for why, I pray?

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: Why? marry they had come in with some city show else, hired a few tinsel coats at the vizard-makers, which would ha' made them look, for all world, like bakers in their linen bases, and mealy vizards, new come from bolting. I saw a show once at the marriage of a magnificero's daughter, presented by time: which time was an old bald thing; a servant, 'twas the best man; he was a dyer, and came in likeness of the rainbow in all manner of colours, to show his art, but the rainbow smelled of urine, so we were all afraid the property was changed, and looked for a shower. Then came in after him, one that (It seemed) feared no colours, a grocer that had trimmed up himself handsomely: he was justice, and showed reasons why. And I think this grocer, I mean this justice, had borrowed a weather-beaten balance from some justice of a conduit, both which scales were replenished with the choice of his ware, and the more liberally to show his nature, he gave every woman in the room her handful.

sp.speaker: Thais.
sp.p: O great act of justice! well, and my husband come cleanly off with this, he shall ne'er betray his weakness more, but confess himself a citizen hereafter, and acknowledge their wit, for alas they come short.

div.stage: Enter in the masque, the count of Arsena, Mendosa, Claridiana, torch-bearers. They deliver the shields to their several mistresses, that is to say. Mendosa, to the lady Lentulus; Claridiana, to Abigal; to Isabella, Gvido count of Arsena; to Thais, Rogero.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Good my lord, be my expositor. To the Cardinal.

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: The sun setting, a man pointing at it:
The motto, senso ã€ˆâ€¦ã€‰ calarem:
fair bride, some servant of yours, that here imitates
To have felt the heat of love bred in your brightness,
But setting thus from him, by marriage,
He only here acknowledgeth your power,
And must expect beams of a morrow sun.

sp.speaker: Lent.
sp.p: Lord bridegroom, will you interpret me?

sp.speaker: Rober.
sp.l: A sable shield: the word, vidua spes.
What the forlorn hope, in black, despairing?
Lady Lentulus, is this the badge of all your suitors?

sp.speaker: Lent.
sp.p: I by my troth my lord, if they come to me.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: I could give it another interpretation. Methinks this lover has learned, of women, to deal by contraries: if so, then here he says, the widow is his only hope.

sp.speaker: Lent.
sp.p: No: good my lord, let the first stand.

sp.speaker: Rober.
sp.p: Inquire of him, and he'll resolve the doubt.

sp.speaker: Abig.
sp.l: What's here? A ship sailing nigh her haven?
With good ware belike: 'tis well ballast.

sp.speaker: Thais.
sp.p: O, your this device smells of the merchant. What's your ship's name, I pray? The forlorn hope?

sp.speaker: Abigall.
sp.p: No: the merchant royal.

sp.speaker: Thais.
sp.p: And why not adventurer?

sp.speaker: Abig.
sp.p: You see no likelihood of that: would it not fain be in the haven? The word, ut tangerem portum.

lg.l: Marry, for ought I know, God grant it. What's there?

sp.speaker: Thais.
sp.p:
Mine's an azure shield: marry what else; I should tell thee more than I understand; but the word is,
Aut precio, aut precibus.

sp.speaker: Abigall.
sp.p: Ay, ay, some common-counsel device. They take the women, and dance the first change.

sp.speaker: Mend.
sp.p: Fair widow, how like you this change?

sp.speaker: Lent.
sp.p: I changed too lately to like any.

sp.speaker: Mend.
sp.l: O your husband! you wear his memory like a deaths-head.
For heaven's love think of me as of the man
Whose dancing days you see are not yet done.

sp.speaker: Lent.
sp.p: Yet you sink apace sir.

sp.speaker: Mend.
sp.p: The fault's in my upholsterer, lady.

sp.speaker: Roger.
sp.l: Thou shalt as soon find truth telling a lie,
Virtue a bawd, honesty a courtier,
as me turned recreant to thy least design:
Love makes me speak, and he makes love divine.

sp.speaker: Thais.
sp.l: Would love could make you so: but 'tis his guise
To let us surfeit ere he open our eyes.

sp.speaker: Abig.
sp.l: You grasp my hand too hard i'faith, fair sir,Holding her by the hand.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Not as you grasp my heart, unwilling wanton.
Were but my breast bare and anatomised,
Thou shouldst behold there how thou torturest it:
And as Appelles limbed the Queen of love,
In her right hand grasping a heart in flames,
So may I thee, fairer, but crueler.

sp.speaker: Abig.
sp.p: Well sir, your vizor gives you colour for what you say.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Grace me to wear this favour, 'tis a gem
That veils to your eyes, though not to th'eagles,
And in exchange give me one word of comfort.

sp.speaker: Abig.
sp.l: I marry: I like this wooer well:
He'll win's pleasure out o'the stones. The second change. Isabella falls in love with Rogero when the changers speak.

sp.speaker: Is.
sp.l: Change is no robbery: yet in this change
Thou robbest me of my heart, sure Cupid's here,
Disguised like a pretty torchbearer,
And makes his brand a torch, that with more sleight
He may entrap weak women: here the sparks
Fly as in Aetna from his father's anvil.
O powerful boy! my heart's on fire, and unto mine eyes
The raging flames ascend, like to two beacons,
Summoning my strongest powers, but all too late,
The conqueror already opens the gate.
I will not ask his name.

sp.speaker: Abig.
sp.p: You dare put it into my hands.

sp.speaker: Mend.
sp.p: Zounds, do you think I will not?

sp.speaker: Abig.
sp.p: Then thus, tomorrow (You'll be secret, servant.)

sp.speaker: Mend.
sp.p: All that I do, I'll do in secret.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: My husband goes to Mawrano to renew the farm he has.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Well, what time goes the jakes-farmer?

sp.speaker: Abig.
sp.p:
He shall not be long out, but you shall put in, I warrant you. Have a care that you stand just i'the nick about six o'clock in the evening; my maid shall conduct you up, to save
mine honour you must come up darkling, and to avoid suspicion.

sp.speaker: Mend.
sp.p: Zounds, hoodwinked, and if you'll open all sweet lady.

sp.speaker: Abig.
sp.p: But if you fail to do't.

sp.speaker: Mend.
sp.p: The sun shall fail the day first.

sp.speaker: Abig.
sp.l: Tie this ring fast, you may be sure to know.
You'll brag of this, now you have brought me to the bay.

sp.speaker: Mend.
sp.l: Pox o'this masque: would 'twere done, I might
To my apothecaries for some stirring meats.

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.l: Methinks sir, you should blush e'en through your vizor,
I have scarce patience to dance out the rest.

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.l: The worse my fate that ploughs a marble quarry:
Primaleon yet thy image was more kind,
Although thy love not half so true as mine.
Dance they that list, I sail against the wind.

sp.speaker: Thais.
sp.l: Nay sir, betray not your infirmities,
You'll make my husband jealous by and by;
We will think of you, and that presently.

sp.speaker: Guid.
sp.l: The spheres ne'er danced unto a better tune.
Sound music there.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: 'Twas music that he spoke. The third change ended, ladies fall off.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Gallants I thank you, and begin a health to your mistresses.

sp.speaker: 3. or 4.
sp.p: Fair thanks sir bridegroom.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: He speaks not to this pledge, has he no mistress?
Would I might choose one for him: but't may beRogero dances a Laualto, or a galliard, and in the midst of it, falleth into the bride's lap, but straight leaps up, and danceth it out.
He doth adore a brighter star than we.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Sit ladies sit, you have had standing long.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Bless the man: spritely and nobly done.

sp.speaker: Thais.
sp.p: What, is your ladyship hurt?

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: O no, an easy fall.
Was I not deep enough, thou god of lust,
But I must further wade? I am his now,
As sure as Juno's Jove's, Hymen take flight,
And see not me, 'tis not my wedding night. Exit Isabella.

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.p: The brides departed, discontent it seems.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: We'll after her. Gallants, unmask I pray,
And taste a homely banquet we entreat. Exit Rob. Card. and lights.

sp.speaker: Clarid.
sp.p: Candidi Ernigos I beseech thee.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Come widow, I'll be bold to put you in.
My lord will you have a sociate? Exit Thais.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: Good gentlemen if I have any interest in you,Lent. Abig.
Let me depart unknown, 'tis a disgrace
Of an eternal memory.

sp.speaker: Mend.
sp.p: What the fall my lord, as common a thing as can be, the stiffest man in Italy may fall between a woman's legs.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Would I had changed places with you my lord, would it had been my hap.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: What cuckold laid his horns in my way?
Signior Claridiana, you were by the lady when I fell,
Do you think I hurt her?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: You could not her, my lord, between the legs.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: What was't I fell withal?

sp.speaker: Mend.
sp.p: A cross point my lord.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: Cross-point indeed: well if you love me, let me hence unknown,
The silence yours, the disgrace mine own. Ex. Clar. and Mend.

div.stage: Enter Isabella with a gilt goblet and meets Rogero.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: Sir, if wine were nectar I'll begin a health,
To her that were most gracious in your eye,
Yet deign, as simply 'tis the gift of Bacchus,
To give her pledge that drinks: this god of wine
Cannot inflame me more to appetite,
Though he be co-supreme with mighty love,
Than thy fair shape.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Zounds she comes to deride me.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: That kiss shall serve
To be a pledge although my lips should starve.
No trick to get that vizor from his face?

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: I will steal hence, and so conceal disgrace.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Sir, have you left naught behind?

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: Yes, lady but the fates will not permit
(As gems once lost are seldom or never found)
I should convey it with me. Sweet goodnight.
She bends to me: there's my fall again. Exit.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: He's gone, that lightning that a while doth strike
our eyes with amazed brightness, and on a sudden
Leaves us in prisoned darkness. Lust thou art high,
My smiles may well come from the sky.
Anna, Anna. Enter Anna.

sp.speaker: Anna.
sp.p: Madam, did you call?

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: Follow yond stranger, prithee learn his name:
We may hereafter thank him. How I dote? Exit Anna.
Is he not a god
That can command what other men would win
With the hardest advantage? I must have him,
Or shadowlike follow his fleeting steps.
Were I as Daphne, and he followed chase,
Though I rejected young Apollo's love,
And like a dream beguile his wand'ring steps,
Should he pursue me through the neighbouring grove,
Each cowslip stalk should trip a willing fall,
Till he were mine, who till then am his thrall:
Nor will I blush, since worthy is my chance.
'Tis said that Venus with a satire slept,
And how much short came she of my fair aim?
Then Queen of love a precedent I'll be,
To teach fair women learn to love of me.
Speak music, what's his name. Enter Anna.

sp.speaker: Anna.
sp.p: Madam, it was the worthy count Massino.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: Blessed be thy tongue: the worthy count indeed,
The worthiest of the worthies. Trusty Anna,
Hast thou packed up those moneys, plate, and jewels
I gave direction for?

sp.speaker: Anna.
sp.l: Yes, madam, I have trussed up them, that many
A proper man has been trussed up for.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: I thank thee, take the wings of night,
Beloved secretary, and post with them to Swevia,
There furnish up some stately palace
Worthy to entertain the King of love:
Prepare it for my coming and my loves,
Ere Phoebus steeds once more unharnessed be,
Or ere he sport with his beloved Thetis,
the silver-footed goddess of the sea,
We will set forward. Fly like the Northern wind,
Or swifter, Anna, fleet like to my mind.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: I am just of your mind madam, I am gone. Exit An.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: So to the house of death the mourner goes,
That is bereft of what his soul desired,
As I to bed, I to my nuptial bed,
The heaven on earth: so to thought slaughters went
The pale Andromeda bedewed with tears,
When every minute she expected gripes of a fell monster,
And in vain bewailed the act of her creation.
Sullen night that lookest with sunk eyes on my nuptial bed,
With ne'er a star that smiles upon the end,
Mend thy slack pace, and lend the malcontent,
The hoping lover, and the wishing bride
Beams that too long thou shadowest: or if not
In spite of thy fixed front when my loathed mate
Shall struggle in due pleasure for his right,
I'll think't my love, and die in that delight. Exit.

div.stage: Enter at several doors Abigal and Thais.

sp.speaker: Abig.
sp.l: Thais, you're an early riser.
I have that to show will make your hair stand on-end.

sp.speaker: Thais.
sp.p: Well lady, and I have that to show you will bring your courage down. What would you say, and I would name a party saw your husband court, kiss, nay almost go through for the hole?

sp.speaker: Abig.
sp.p: How, how, what would I say? nay, by this light, what would I not do? If ever Amazon fought better, or more at the face then I'll do, let me never be thought a new married wife. Come unmask her: 'tis some admirable creature, whose beauty you need not paint. I warrant you, 'tis done to your hand.

sp.speaker: Thais.
sp.l: Would any woman but I â–ª be abused to her face?
Prithee read the contents: know'st thou the character?

sp.speaker: Abig.
sp.p:
'Tis my husband's hand, and a love-letter: but for the contents I find none in it. Has the lustful monster, all back and belly-starved me thus? What defect does he see in me? I'll be sworn wench, I am of as pliant and yielding body
to him, e'en which way he will, he may turn me as he list himself. What? and dedicate to thee: I marry, here's a style so high, as a man cannot help a dog o'er it. He was wont to write to me in the city phrase, my good Abigall: here's astonishment of nature, unparalleled excellency, and most unequal rarity of creation: three such words will turn any honest woman in the world whore: for a woman is never won till she know not what to answer; and beshrew me if I understand any of these: you are the party I perceive, and here's a white sheet, that your husband has promised me to do penance in: you must not think to dance the shaking of the sheets alone though there be not such rare phrases in't, 'tis more to the matter; a legible hand, but for the dash, or the (He) and (As): short bawdy parenthesis as ever you saw, to the purpose: he has not left out a prick I warrant you, wherein he has promised to do me any good, but the law's in mine own hand.

sp.speaker: Thais.
sp.p: I ever thought by his red beard he would prove a Judas, here am I bought and sold; he makes much of me indeed. Well wench, we were best wisely in time seek for prevention, I should be loath to take drink and die on't, as I am afraid I shall that he will lie with thee.

sp.speaker: Abig.
sp.p: To be short sweet heart, I'll be true to thee, though a liar to my husband: I have signed your husband's bill like a wood cock as he is held, persuaded him (Since naught but my love can assuage his violent passions) he should enjoy, like a private friend, the pleasures of my bed: I told him my husband was to go to Mawrano today, to renew a farm he has, and in the mean time he might be tenant at will, to use mine: this false fire has so taken with him, that he's ravished afore he come. I have had stones on him all red: dost know this:

sp.speaker: Thais.
sp.p: Ay, too well, it blushes for his Mr.. Points to the ring.

sp.speaker: Abigall.
sp.l: Now my husband will be hawking about thee anon,
And thou canst meet him closely.

sp.speaker: Thais.
sp.p: By my faith I would be loath in the dark, and he knew me.

sp.speaker: Abig.
sp.p:
I mean thus: the same occasion will serve him too, they are birds of a feather, and will fly together, I warrant
thee wench, appoint him to come: say that thy husband's gone for Mawrano, and tell me anon if thou madest not his heartblood spring, for joy, in his face.

sp.speaker: Thais.
sp.p: I conceive you not all this while.

sp.speaker: Abig.
sp.p: Then thou'rt a barren woman, and no marvel if thy husband love thee not: the hour for both to come is six, a dark time fit for purblind lovers; and with cleanly conveyance by the niglers our maids, they shall be translated into our bedchambers.
sp.l: Your husband into mine, and mine into yours.

sp.speaker: Thais.
sp.p: But you mean they shall come in at the backdoors.

sp.speaker: Abig.
sp.p: Who, our husbands? nay, and they come not in at the fore-doors, there will be no pleasure in't. But we two will climb over our garden-pales, and come in that way, (The chastest that are in Venice will stray for a good turn) and thus wittily will we be bestowed, you into my house to your husband, and I into your house to my husband, and I warrant thee before a month come to an end, they'll crack louder of this nights-lodging, than the bedsteads.

sp.speaker: Thais.
sp.p: All is if our maids keep secret.

sp.speaker: Abig.
sp.p: Mine is a maid I'll be sworn, she has kept her secrets hitherto.

sp.speaker: Thais.
sp.p: Troth, and I never had any sea-captain boarded in my house.

sp.speaker: Abig.
sp.l: Go to then: and the better to avoid suspicion,
sp.p: Thus we must insist, they must come up darkling, recreate themselves with their delight an hour or two, and after a million of kisses, or so.

sp.speaker: Thais.
sp.p: But is my husband content to come darkling?

sp.speaker: Abig.
sp.p: What not to save mine honour? he that will run through fire, as he has professed, will by the heat of his love, grope in the dark. I warrant him he shall save mine honour.

sp.speaker: Thais.
sp.p: I am afraid my voice will discover me.

sp.speaker: Abig.
sp.p: Why then, you're best say nothing, and take it thus quietly when your husband comes.

sp.speaker: Thais.
sp.p: Ay, but you know a woman cannot choose but speak in these cases.

sp.speaker: Abig.
sp.l: Bite in your nether-lip, and I warrant you,
Or make as if you were whiffing tobacco;
Or such like me. Gods-so, I hear thy husband. Exit.

sp.speaker: Thais.
sp.p: Farewell wise-woman.

div.stage: Enter Mizaldus.

sp.speaker: Mizal.
sp.l: Now begins my vengeance mount high in my lust:
'Tis a rare creature, she'll do't i'faith;
And I am armed at all points â–ª a rare whiblin,
To be revenged, and yet gain pleasure in't,
One height above revenge: yet what a slave am I,
Are there not younger brothers enough, but we must
Branch one another? o but mine's revenge,
And who on that does dream
Must be a tyrant ever in extreme.
O my wife Thais get my breakfast ready,
I must into the country to a farm I have
Some two miles off, and, as I think,
Shall not come home tonight . Jaques, Jaques,
Get my vessel ready to row me down the river.
Prithee make haste sweet girl. Exit Mizal.

sp.speaker: Thais.
sp.p: So, there's one fool shipped away: are your cross-points discovered? Get your breakfast ready!

lg.l: By this light I'll tie you to hard fare:
I have been too sparing of that you prodigally offer
Voluntary to another: well you shall be a tame fool hereafter.
The finest light is when we first defraud;
Husband tonight 'tis I must lie abroad. Exit.

div.stage: Enter Isabella and a page with a letter.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: Here, take this letter, bear it to the count:
But boy, first tell me; think'st thou I am in love?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: Madam, I cannot tell.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: Canst thou not tell? Dost thou not see my face?
Is not the face the index of the mind?
And canst thou not distinguish love by that?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: No madam.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: Then take this letter and deliver it
Unto the worthy count. No, fie upon him,
come back again: tell me, why shouldst thou think
That same's a love-letter?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: I do not think so madam.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: I know thou dost: for thou dost ever use
To hold the wrong opinion. Tell me true,
Dost thou not think that letter is of love?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: If you would have me think so madam, yes.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: What dost thou think thy lady is so fond?
Give me the letter, thyself shall see it.
Yet I should tear it in the breaking ope,
And make him lay a wrongful charge on thee;
And say thou brok'st it open by the way;
And saw what heinous things I charge him with:
But 'tis all one, the letter is not of love,
Therefore deliver it unto himself,
And tell him he's deceived, I do not love him.
But if he think so bid him come to me,
And I'll confute him straight; I'll show him reasons,
I'll show him plainly why I cannot love him.
And if he hap to read it in thy hearing,
Or chance to tell thee that the words were sweet,
Do not thou then disclose my lewd intent,
Under those Siren words, and how I mean
To use him when I have him at my will:
For then thou wilt destroy the plot that's laid,
And make him fear to yield when I do wish
Only to have him yield; for when I have him,
None but myself shall know how I will use him.
Be gone, why stayest thou? yet return again.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: I madam.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: Why dost thou come again? I bade thee go.
If I say, go, never return again. Exit page.
My blood, like to a troubled ocean,
Cuffed with the winds, incertain where to rest,
Butts at the utmost share of every limb.
My husband's not the man I would have had:
Oh my new thoughts to this brave sprightly lord,
was fixed to that hid fire lovers feel:
Where was my mind before, that refined judgement,
That represents rare objects to our passions?
Or did my lust beguile me of my sense?
Making me feast upon such dangerous cates,
For present want, that needs must breed a surfeit:
How was I shipwrecked? yet Isabella think
Thy husband is a noble gentleman, young, wise,
And rich: think what fate follows thee,
And naught but lust doth blind thy worthy love:
I will desist. O no, it may not be.
Even as a headstrong courser bears away
His rider, vainly striving him to stay.
Or as a sudden gale thrusts into sea
The heaven-touching bark, now near the lee:
So wavering Cupid brings me back again,
And purple love resumes his darts again:
Here of themselves, thy shafts come as if shot:
Better than I thy quiver knows 'em not

div.stage: Enter count Arsena, and a page.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: Madam: the count.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: So fell the Trojan wanderer on the Greek,
And bore away his ravished prize to Troy:
For such a beauty, brighter than his Dana.
Jove should ( methinks ) now come himself again â–ª
Lovely Isabella, I confess me mortal:
Not worthy to serve thee in thought, I swear,
Yet shall not this same overflow of favour
Diminish my vowed duty to your beauty.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: Your love, my lord, I blushingly proclaim it,
Hath power to draw me through a wilderness,
Were't armed with furies, as with furious beasts.
Boy, bid our train be ready, we'll to horse. Ex. page.
My lord, I should say something, but I blush,
Courting is not befitting to our sex.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: I'll teach you how to woo,
Say you have loved me long,
and tell me that a woman's feeble tongue
Was never tuned unto a wooing-string;
Yet for my sake you will forget your sex,
And court my love with strained immodesty,
Then bid me make you happy with a kiss.

sp.speaker: Is.
sp.l: Sir, though women do not woo, yet for your sake,
I am content to leave that civil custom,
And pray you kiss me.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: Now use some unexpect umbages,
To draw me further into Vulcan's net.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: You love not me so well as I love you.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Fair lady, but I do.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Then show your love.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: Why in this kiss I show't, and in my vowed service,
This wooing shall suffice, 'tis easier far
To make the current of a silver-brook
Convert his flowing backward to his spring,
Then turn a woman wooer. There's no cause
Can turn the settled course of nature's laws.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: My lord, will you pursue the plot?

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: The letter gives direction here for Pavie.
To horse, to horse: thus once Eridace,
With looks regardant, did the Thracian gaze,
And lost his gift, while he desired the sight.
But wiser I, lead by more powerful charm;
I'd see the world win thee from out mine arm. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter at several doors, Claridiana and Gvido.

sp.speaker: Gui.
sp.p: Zounds, is the Huritano coming? Claridiana what's theA trampling of horses heard.matter?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: The countess of Swevia has new taken horse.
Fly Phoebus, fly, the hour is six o'clock .

sp.speaker: Guid.
sp.p: Whither is she going signior?

sp.speaker: Clarid.
sp.l: Even as Jove went to meet his simile.
To the devil I think.

sp.speaker: Guido.
sp.p: You know not wherefore?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: To say sooth I do not.
So in immortal wise shall I arrive.

sp.speaker: Guid.
sp.p: At the gallows. What in a passion signior?

sp.speaker: Clarid.
sp.l: Zounds, do not hold me sir:
Beauteous Thais, I am all thine wholly.
The staff is now advancing for the rest,
And when I tilt, Mizaldus aware thy crest. Exit.

div.stage: Enter Roberto, in his nightgown, and cap, with servants, he kneels down.

sp.speaker: Guid.
sp.p: What's here? the capering codshead tilting in the air?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: The gods send her no horse, a poor old age.
Eternal woe, and sickness lasting rage.

sp.speaker: Guid.
sp.p: My lord, you may yet o'ertake 'em.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Furies supply that place, for I will not: no,
She that can forsake me when pleasure's in the full,
Fresh and untired, what would she on the least barren coldness?
I warrant you she has already got
Her bravoes, and her ruffians: the meanest whore
Will have one buckler, but your great ones more.
The shores of Sicily retains not such a monster,
Though to galley-slaves they daily prostitute.
To let the nuptial tapers give light to her new lust,
Who would have thought it?
She that could no more forsake my company,
Then can the day forsake the glorious presence of the sun.
When I was absent, than her galled eyes
Would have shed April showers, and outwept
The clouds in that same overpassionate mood:
When they drowned all the world, yet now forsakes me:
Women your eyes shed glances like the sun:
Now shines your brightness, now your light is done.
On the sweetest flowers you shine, 'tis but by chance,
And on the basest weed you'll waste a glance.
Your beams once lost can never more be found:
Unless we wait until your course run round,
(And take you at fist hand.) Since I cannot
Enjoy the noble title of a man,
But after-ages, as our virtues are
Buried whilst we are living, will sound out
My infamy, and her degenerate shame;
yet in my life I'll smother't if I may,
And, like a dead man, to the world bequeath
These houses of vanity, Mils, and lands.
Take what you will, I will not keep among you servants,
And welcome some religious monastery,
A true sworn beadsman I'll hereafter be,
And wake the morning cock with holy prayers.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: Good my lord: noble master.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Dissuade me not, my will shall be my King;
I thank thee wife, a fair change thou hast given,
I leave thy lust to woo the love of heaven. Exit cum servis.

sp.speaker: Guid.
sp.l: This is conversion, is't not? as good as might have been,
He turns religious upon his wives turning courtesan.
This is just like some of our gallant prodigals,
When they have consumed their patrimonies wrongfully,
They turn Capuchins for devotion,Exit.

div.head: Actus tertij
Scaena prima.
div.stage: Claridiana, and Rogero being in a readiness, are received in at one another's houses by their maids.
Then enter Mendosa, with a page, to the lady Lentulus' window.

sp.speaker: Mendosa.
sp.l: Night like a solemn mourner frowns on earth,
Envying that day should force her doff her robes,
Or Phoebus chase away her melancholy.
Heaven's eyes look faintly through her sable mask,
And silver Cinthia hies her in her sphere,
Scorning to grace black night's solemnity.
Be unpropitious night to villain thoughts,
But let thy diamonds shine on virtuous love:
This is the lower house of high-built heaven,
where my chaste Phoebe sits, enthroned among thoughts
So purely good, brings her to heaven on earth.
Such power hath souls in contemplation.
Sing boy (Though night yet) like the morning's lark:Music plays.
A soul that's clear is light, though heaven be dark.

div.stage: The lady Lentulus, at her window.

sp.speaker: Lent.
sp.p: Who speaks in music to us?

sp.speaker: Mend.
sp.p: Sweet, 'tis I. Boy, leave me, and to bed. Exit page.

sp.speaker: Lent.
sp.p: I thank you for your music: now goodnight.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Leave not the world yet, Queen of chastity,
Keep promise with thy love Endymion â–ª
And let me meet thee there on Latmus' top.
'Tis I whose virtuous hopes are firmly fixed
On the fruition of thy chaste vowed love.

sp.speaker: Lent.
sp.p: My lord, your honour made me promise your ascent into my house, since my vow barred my doors,
sp.l: By some wit's engine, made for theft and lust:
Yet for your honour, and my humble fame,
Check your bloods passions, and return dear lord:
Suspicion is a dog that still doth bite.
Without a cause, this act gives food to envy;
Swollen big, it bursts, and poisons our clear flames.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Envy is stingless when she looks on thee.

sp.speaker: Lent.
sp.p: Envy is blind, my lord, and cannot see.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: If you break promise, fair, you break my heart.

sp.speaker: Lent.
sp.l: Then come. Yet stay. Ascend. Yet let us part.
I fear, yet know not what I fear:
Your love's precious, yet mine honour's dear.

sp.speaker: Mend.
sp.l: If I do stain thy honour with foul lust,
May thunder strike me, to show Jove is just.

sp.speaker: Lent.
sp.l: Then come my lord, on earth your vow is given.
This aid I'll lend you. He throws up a ladder of cords, which she makes fast to some part of the window, he asends, and at top falls.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Thus I mount my heaven.
Receive me sweet.

sp.speaker: Lent.
sp.l: O me unhappy wretch.
How fares your honour? speak fate-crossed lord.
If life retain his seat within you, speak;
else like that Sestian dame, that saw her love,
Cast by the frowning billows, on the sands,
And lean death swollen big with the Hellespont,
In bleak Leander's body, like his love,
Come I to thee, one grave shall serve us both.

sp.speaker: Mend.
sp.l: Stay miracle of women, yet I breathe,
Though death be entered in this tower of flesh,
He is not conqueror, my heart stands out,
And yields to thee, scorning his tyranny.

sp.speaker: Lent.
sp.l: My doors are vowed shut, and I cannot help you.
Your wounds are mortal, wounded is mine honour,
If there the town-guard find you. Unhappy dame,
Relief is perjured, my vow kept, shame.
What hellish destiny did twist my fate?

sp.speaker: Mend.
sp.l: Rest cease thine eyelids; be not passionate:
Sweet sleep secure, I'll remove myself.
That viper envy shall not spot thy fame:
I'll take that poison with me, my soul's rest,
For like a serpent, I'll creep on my breast.

sp.speaker: Lent.
sp.p: Thou more than man, love-wounded: joy and grief fight in my blood. Thy wounds and constancy are both so strong none can have victory.

sp.speaker: Mend.
sp.l: Darken the world, earths-queen, get thee to bed;
The earth is light while those two stars are spread:
Their splendour will betray me to men's eyes.
Veil thy bright face: for if thou longer stay,
Phoebus will rise to thee, and make night day.

sp.speaker: Lent.
sp.p: To part and leave you hurt my soul doth fear.

sp.speaker: Mend.
sp.p: To part from hence I cannot, you being there.

sp.speaker: Lent.
sp.l: We'll move together, than fate love controls,
And as we part so bodies part from souls.

sp.speaker: Mend.
sp.l: Mine is the earth, thine the refined fire:
I am mortal, thou divine, than soul mount higher.

sp.speaker: Lent.
sp.p: Why then take comfort sweet, I'll see you tomorrow. Exit.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: My wounds are nothing, thy loss breeds my sorrow.
See now 'tis dark.
Support your master, legs, a little further:
faint not bold heart with anguish of my wound:
Try further yet, can blood weigh down my soul?
Desire is vain without ability. He staggars on, and then falls down.
Thus falls a monarch, if fate push at him.

div.stage: Enter a captain and the watch.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Come on my hearts, we are the city's security, I'll give you your charge, and then like courtiers every man spy out: let no man in my company be afraid to speak to a cloak lined with velvet, nor tremble at the sound of a gingling spur.

sp.speaker: 1 watchman
sp.p: May I never be counted a cock of the game, if I fear spurs: but be gelded like a capon for the preserving of my voice.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: I'll have none of my band refrain to search a venereal house, though his wife's sister be a lodger there: nor take two shillings of the bawd to save the gentlemen's credits that are aloft: and so like voluntary panders leave them, to the shame of all halberdiers.
Nay, for the wenches, we'll tickle them, that's flat.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: If you meet a shevoiliero, that's in the gross phrase, a knight, that swaggers in the street, and being taken, has no money in his purse to pay for his fees; it shall be a part of your duty to entreat me to let him go.
O marvellous his there such chevaliers?
Some 200. that's the least, that are revealed. Mend. groves.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: What groan is that? bring a light. Who lies there?
It is the lord Mendosa, kinsman to our Duke.
Speak good my lord, relate your dire mischance:
Life like a fearful servant flies his master,
Art must atone them, or'th' whole man is lost.
Convey him to a surgeon's, than return:
No place shall be unsearched until we find
The truth of this mischance. Make haste again. Exit the watch. Manet captain.
Whose house is this stands open? in, and search.
What guests that house contains, and bring them forth.
This nobleman's misfortune stirs my quiet,
And fills my soul with fearful fantasies.
But I'll unwind this labyrinth of doubt,
else industry shall lose part of itself's labour. Enter the watch, with Claridiana and Rogero taken in one another's houses, in their shirts and night-gowns, they see one another.
Who have we there? Signiors cannot you tell us
How our prince's kinsman came wounded to the death
Nigh to your houses.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: Heyday; cross-ruff at midnight. Is't Christmas?
You go a gaming to your neighbour's house.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Dost make a mummer of me ox-head?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Make answer gentlemen, it doth concern you.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Ox-head will bear an action; I'll ha'the law; I'll not be yoked. Bear witness gentlemen, he calls me ox-head.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Do you hear sir?

sp.speaker: Clarid.
sp.p: Very well, very well, take law and hang thyself, I care not. Had she no other but that good face to dote upon? I'd rather she had dealt with a dangerous Frenchman, then with such a pagan.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Are you mad? answer my demand.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: I am as good a christian as thyself,
Though my wife have now new christened me.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Are you deaf, you make no answer?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Would I had had the circumcising of thee Jew, I'd ha'
Cut short your cuckold-maker, I would i'faith, I would i'faith.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Away with them to prison; they'll answer better there.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Not to fast gentlemen: what's our crime?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Murder of the Duke's kinsman, signior Mendosa.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.p: Nothing else? we did it, we did it, we did it.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Take heed gentlemen what you confess.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: I'll confess any thing since I am made a fool by a knave.
I'll be hanged like an innocent, that's flat.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: I'll not see my shame. Hemp in stead of a quacksalver, you shall put out mine eyes, and my head shall be bought to make inkhorns of.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: You do confess the murder?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Sir, 'tis true,
Done by a faithless christian and a Jew.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: To prison with them, we will hear no further,
The tongue betrays the heart of guilty murder.

div.stage: Exeunt omnes.
Enter count Gvido, Isabella, Anna, and servants.

sp.speaker: Guid.
sp.l: Welcome to Pavy sweet, and may this kiss
Chase melancholy from thy company:
Speak my soul's joy, how fare you after travail.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: Like one that scapeth dangers on the seas,
Yet trembles with cold fears being safe on land,
With bare imagination of what's past.

sp.speaker: Guid.
sp.p: Fear keep with cowards, aire-stars cannot move.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Fear in this kind, my lord, doth sweeten love.

sp.speaker: Guid.
sp.p: To think fear joy (Dear) I cannot conjecture.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: Fear's sire to fervency,
Which makes love's sweet prone nectar:
Trembling desire, fear, hope, and doubtful leisure,
Distil from love the quintessence of pleasure.

sp.speaker: Guid.
sp.l: Madam, I yield to you; fear keeps with love,
My oratory is too weak against you:
You have the ground of knowledge, wise experience,
Which makes your argument invincible.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: You are times scholar, and can flatter weakness.

sp.speaker: Guid.
sp.l: Custom allows it, and we plainly see
Princes and women maintain flattery.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: Anna, go see my jewels and my trunks
Be aptly placed in their several rooms. Exit Anna.
sp.stage: Enter Gniaca count of Gaza, with attendants.
sp.l: My lord, know you this gallant? 'tis a complete gentleman.

sp.speaker: Guid.
sp.p: I do; 'tis count Guiaca, my endeared friend.

sp.speaker: Gniac.
sp.l: Welcome to Pavie, welcome fairest lady:
Your sight dear friend, is life's restorative;
This day's the period of long-wished content,
More welcome to me then day to the world,
Night to the wearied, or gold to a miser;
Such joy feels friendship in society.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: A rare shaped man: compare them both together,

sp.speaker: Guid.
sp.l: Our loves are friendly twins, both at a birth;
The joy you taste, that joy do I conceive,
This day's the jubilee of my desire.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: He's fairer than he was when first I saw him.
This little time makes him more excellent.

sp.speaker: Gniac.
sp.l: Relate some news. Hark you, what lady's that â–ª
Be open breasted, so will I to thee. They whisper.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: Error did blind him that paints love blind;
For my love plainly judge's difference:
Love is clear sighted, and with eagles eyes,
Undazzled, looks upon bright sun-beamed beauty:
Nature did rob herself, when she made him.
Blushing to see her work excel herself â–ª
'Tis shape makes mankind semelacie.
Forgive me Rogero, 'tis my fate
To love thy friend, and quit thy love with hate.
I must enjoy him, let hope thy passions smother:
Faith cannot cool blood; I'll clip him, were't my brother.
Such is the heat of my sincere affection,
Hell nor earth can keep love in subjection.

sp.speaker: Gnia.
sp.l: I crave your honours pardon my ignorance
Of what you were, may gain a courteous pardon.

sp.speaker: Is.
sp.l: There needs no pardon, where there's no offence;
His tongue strikes music ravishing my sense:
I must be sudden, else desire confounds me.

sp.speaker: Guid.
sp.l: What sport affords this climate for delight?

sp.speaker: Gnia.
sp.l: We'll hawk and hunt today, as for tomorrow
Variety shall feed variety.

sp.speaker: Is.
sp.l: Dissimulation women's armour is,
Aid love belief, and female constancy.
O, I am sick my lord, kind Rogero help me.

sp.speaker: Guido.
sp.l: Forfend it heaven, madam sit; how fare you?
My life's best comfort speak, oh speak sweet saint.

sp.speaker: Is.
sp.l: Fetch art to keep life, run my love, I faint:
My vital breath runs coldly through my veins,
I see lean death with eyes imaginary,
Stand fearfully before me: here my end
A wife unconstant, yet thy loving friend.

sp.speaker: Guid.
sp.p: As swift as thought, fly I to wish thee aid. Exit.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: Thus innocence by craft is soon betrayed.
My lord Guiaca, 'tis your art must heal me,
I am lovesick for your love; love, love, for loving:
I blush for speaking truth; fair sir believe me,
Beneath the moon naught but your frown can grieve me.

sp.speaker: Gniaca.
sp.p: Lady, by heaven, methinks , this fit is strange.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: Count not my love light for this sudden change:
By Cupid's bow I swear, and will avow,
I never knew true perfect love till now.

sp.speaker: Gniac.
sp.l: Wrong not yourself, me, and your dearest friend,
Your love is violent, and soon will end.
Love is not love unless love doth persever,
That love is perfect love, that loves for ever.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: Such love is mine, believe it well-shaped youth,
Though women use to lie, yet I speak truth.
Give sentence for my life or speedy death:
Can you affect me?

sp.speaker: Gniac.
sp.l: I should belie my thoughts to give denial,
But then to friendship I must turn disloyal:
I will not wrong my friend, let that suffice.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: I'll be a miracle, for love a woman dies,Offers to stab herself.

sp.speaker: Gn.
sp.l: Hold madam, these are soul killing passions.
I'd rather wrong my friend than you yourself.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: Love me, or else by Jove death's but delayed:
My vow is fixed in heaven, fear shall not move me,
My life is death with tortures 'less you love me.

sp.speaker: Gnia.
sp.p: Give me some respite, and I will resolve you.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: My heart denies it.
My blood is violent, now or else never,
Love me, and like love's Queen I'll fall before thee,
Enticing dalliance from thee with my smiles,
And steal thy heart with my delicious kisses.
I'll study art in love, that in a rupture
Thy soul shall taste pleasures excelling nature.
Love me, both art and nature in large recompense,
Shall be profuse in ravishing thy sense.

sp.speaker: Gni.
sp.l: You have prevailed, I am yours from all the world,
Thy wit and beauty have entranced my soul:
I long for dalliance, my blood burns like fire,
hell's pain on earth is to delay desire.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: I kiss thee for that breath, this day you hunt;
In midst of all your sports leave you Rogero,
Return to me whose life rests in thy sight,
Where pleasure shall make nectar our delight.

sp.speaker: Gniac.
sp.l: I condescend to what thy will implores me;
He that but now neglected thee, adores thee:Enter Rogero, Anna, doctor.
But see here comes my friend, fear makes him tremble.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: Women are witless that cannot dissemble:
Now I am sick again: where's my lord Rogero?
His love and my health's vanished both together.

sp.speaker: Guid.
sp.l: Wrong not thy friend, dear friend, in thy extremes,
Here's a profound Hipocrates, my dear,
To minister to thee the spirit of health.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: Your sight to me, my lord, excels all physic;
I am better far (My love) then when you left me:
Your friend was comfortable to me at the last.
'Twas but a fit, my lord, and now 'tis past.
Are all things ready sir?

sp.speaker: Anna.
sp.p: Yes madam, the house is fit.

sp.speaker: Gnia.
sp.p: Desire in women is the life of wit. Exeunt omnes.

div.stage: Enter Abigal and Thais at several doors.

sp.speaker: Abig.
sp.p: O partner, I am with child of laughter, and none but you can be my midwife: was there ever such a game at noddy?

sp.speaker: Thais.
sp.p: Our husbands think they are foremen of the jury, they hold the heretic point of predestination, and sure they are born to be hanged.

sp.speaker: Abig.
sp.p: They are like to prove men of judgement, but not for killing of him that's yet alive, and well recovered.

sp.speaker: Thais.
sp.l: As soon as my man saw the watch come up,
All his spirit was down.

sp.speaker: Abig,
sp.l: But though they have made us good sport in speech,
They did hinder us of good sport in action.
O wench, imagination is strong in pleasure.

sp.speaker: Thais.
sp.p: That's true: for the opinion my goodman had of enjoying you, made him do wonders.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Why should weak man, that is so soon satisfied, desire variety?

sp.speaker: Thais.
sp.p: Their answer is, to feed on pheasants continually would breed a loathing.

sp.speaker: Abigall.
sp.p: Then if we seek for strange flesh that have stomachs at will, 'tis pardonable.

sp.speaker: Thais.
sp.p: Ay, if men had any feeling of it, but they judge us by themselves.

sp.speaker: Abig.
sp.p: Well, we will bring them to the gallows, and then, like kind virgins, beg their lives, and after live at our pleasures, and this bridle shall still rein them.

sp.speaker: Thais.
sp.l: Faith, if we were disposed, we might seem as safe,
As if we had the broad seal to warrant it:
But that night's work will stick by me this forty weeks.
Come, shall we go visit the discontented lady Lentulus?
Whom the lord Mendosa has confessed to his chirurgeon,
He would have robbed? I thought great men would but
Have robbed the poor, yet he the rich.

sp.speaker: Abig.
sp.p: He thought that the richer purchase, though with the worse conscience: but we'll to comfort her, and then go hear our husbands lamentations. They say mine has compiled an ungodly volume of satires against women, and calls his book the snarl.

sp.speaker: Thais.
sp.p: But he's in hope his book will save him.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: God defend that it should, or any that snarl in that fashion.

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.l: Well wench, if I could be metamorphosed into thy shape,
I should have my husband pliant to me in his life,
And soon rid of him: for being weary with his continual motion,
He'd die of a consumption.

sp.speaker: Abig.
sp.l: Make much of him, for all our wanton prize,
Follow the proverb, merry be and wise. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Isabella, Anna, and servants.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: Time that devour'st all mortality,
Run swiftly these few hours,
And bring Guiaca on thy aged shoulders,
That I may clip the rarest model of creation.
Do this gentle time
And I will curl thine aged silver lock,
And dally with thee in delicious pleasure.
Medea-like I will renew thy youth;
But if thy frozen steps delay my love,
I'll poison thee with murder, curse thy paths,
And make thee know a time of infamy.
Anna, give watch â–ª and bring me certain notice
When count Guiaca doth approach my house.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Madam I go.
I am kept for pleasure, though I never taste it.
For 'tis the usher's office still to cover
His lady's private meetings with her lover. Exit.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: Desire, thou quenchless flame that burnest our souls,
Cease to torment me;
The dew of pleasure shall put out thy fire,
And quite consume thee with satiety.
Lust shall be cooled with lust, wherein I'll prove,
The life of love is only saved by love. Enter Anna.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Madam, he's coming â–ª

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: Thou blessed Mercury,
Prepare a banquet fit to please the gods;
Let sphere-like music breathe delicious tones
Into our mortal ears; perfume the house
With odoriferous scents, sweeter than myrrh,
Or all the spices in Panchaia:
His sight and touching we will recreate,
That his five senses shall be fivefold happy.
His breath like roses casts out sweet perfume;
Time now with pleasure shall itself consume. Enter Gniaca in his hunting weeds.
How like Adonis in his hunting weeds,
Looks this same goddess tempter?
And art thou come? this kiss entrance thy soul.
Gods I do not envy you; for know this
Way's here on earth complete, excels you bliss:
I'll not change this night's pleasure with you all.

sp.speaker: Gniac.
sp.l: Thou creature made by love, composed of pleasure,
That mak'st true use of thy creation,
In thee both wit and beauty's resident;
Delightful pleasure, unpeered excellence.
This is the fate fixed fast unto thy birth,
That thou alone shouldst be man's heaven on earth:
If I alone may but enjoy thy love,
I'll not change earthly joy to be heaven's Jove:
For though that women haters now are common,
They all shall know earth's joy consists in woman.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: My love was dotage till I loved thee;
For thy soul truly tastes our petulance,
Condition's lover, Cupid's intelligencer,
That makes man understand what pleasure is:
These are fit attributes unto thy knowledge;
For women's beauty o'er men bear that rule.
Our power commands the rich, the wise, the fool.
Though scorn grows big in man in growth and stature,
Yet women are the rarest works in nature.

sp.speaker: Gnia.
sp.l: I do confess the truth, and must admire
That women can command rare man's desire.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: Cease admiration, sit to Cupid's feast,
The preparation to Paphian dalliance,
Harmonious music breathe thy silver airs,
To stir up appetite to Venus' banquet,
That breath of pleasure that entrances souls,
Making that instant happiness a heaven,
In the true taste of love's deliciousness.

sp.speaker: Gniac.
sp.l: Thy words are able to stir cold desire,
Into his flesh that lies entombed in ice,
Having lost the feeling use of warmth in blood,
Then how much more in me, whose youthful veins,
Like a proud river, overflow their bounds?
Pleasure's ambrosia, or love's nourisher,
I long for privacy; come, let us in,
'Tis custom, and not reason makes love sin.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: I'll lead the way to Venus' paradise,
Where thou shalt taste that fruit that made man wise. Exit Isab.

sp.speaker: Gnia.
sp.l: Sing notes of pleasure to elate our blood:
Why should heaven frown on joys that do us good?
I come Isabella keeper of love's treasure,
To force thy blood to lust, and ravish pleasure. Exit.

div.stage: After some short song enter Isabella and Gniaca again, she hanging about his neck laciviously.

sp.speaker: Gniac.
sp.l: Still I am thy captive, yet thy thoughts are free:
To be love's bondman is true liberty.
I have swom in seas of pleasure without ground,
Venturous desire passed depth itself hath drowned.
Such skill has beauty's art in a true lover,
That dead desire to life it can recover.
Thus beauty our desire can soon advance,
Then straight again kill it with dalliance.
Divinest women, your enchanting breathes
Give lovers many lives and many deaths.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: May thy desire to me for ever last,
Not die by surfeit on my delicates:
And as I tie this jewel about thy neck,
So may I tie thy constant love to mine,
Never to seek weaking variety,
That greedy curse of man's and woman's hell,
Where naught but shame and loathed diseases dwell.

sp.speaker: Gniac.
sp.l: You counsel well, dear, learn it then;
For change is given more to you then men.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: My faith to thee, like rocks, shall never move,
The sun shall change his course ere I my love. Enter Anna.

sp.speaker: Anna.
sp.p: Madam, the count Rogero knocks.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: Dear love into my chamber, till I send
My hate from sight.

sp.speaker: Gniac.
sp.p: Lust makes me wrong my friend. Exit Gniaca.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: Anna, stand here, and entertain lord Rogero.
I from my window straight will give him answer.
The serpent's wit to woman rest in me,
By that man fell, then why not he by me?
Feigned sighs and tears dropped from a woman's eye,
Blinds man of reason, strikes his knowledge dumb:
Wit arms a woman, count Rogero come. Exit Isabella.

sp.speaker: Anna.
sp.l: My office still is under: yet in time
Ushers prove masters, degrees makes us climb. Guido knocks.
Who knocks? is't you my noble lord?

div.stage: Enter Gvido in his hunting weeds.

sp.speaker: Guid.
sp.p: Came my friend hither, count Guiaca?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: No, my good lord.

sp.speaker: Guid.
sp.p: Where's my Isabella?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: In her chamber.

sp.speaker: Guid.
sp.p: Good: I'll visit her.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: The chamber's locked my lord: she will be private.

sp.speaker: Guid.
sp.p: Locked against me, my saucy malapert?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Be patient good my lord: she'll give you answer.

sp.speaker: Guid.
sp.p: Isabella life of love, speak, 'tis I that calls. Isab. at her window.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: I must desire your lordship pardon me.

sp.speaker: Guid.
sp.p: Lordship? what's this? Isabella, art thou blind?

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: My lord, my lust was blind, but now my soul's clear sighted,
And sees the spots that did corrupt my flesh:
Those tokens sent from hell, brought by desire,
The messenger of everlasting death.

sp.speaker: Anna.
sp.p: My lady's in her pulpit, now she'll preach.

sp.speaker: Guid.
sp.l: Is not thy lady mad? in verity I always
Took her for a Puritan, and now she shows it.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: Mock not repentance. Profanation
Brings mortals laughing to damnation.
Believe it lord, Isabella's ill past life,
Like gold refined, shall make a perfect wife.
I stand on firm ground now, before on ice;
We know not virtue till we taste of vice.

sp.speaker: Guid.
sp.p: Do you hear dissimulation, woman sinner?

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: Leave my house good my lord, and for my part,
I look for a most wished reconciliation
Betwixt myself and my most wronged husband.
Tempt not contrition then religious lord.
